Details.Description: This file includes the persona of an individual interviewed using the Jobs-to-be-Done (JTBD) framework for a new product. It also contains the full transcript of the qualitative interview, documenting the conversation between the interviewer and the individual.

persona.name: Angela Larson
persona.background_story: Angela grew up in a middle-class family in Portland, Oregon. Her parents, both educators, instilled in her the value of education and empathy. In high school, a volunteer experience at a local hospital led her to pursue nursing. Determined to make a difference in healthcare, she relocated to Seattle for college. Over the years, she has developed a strong professional identity, driven by her belief in providing compassionate care. She values work-life balance, partly from her upbringing where family time was prioritized.

psychographics.values_and_beliefs: Angela values honesty, family, and security. Her career in nursing is a reflection of her belief in helping others and providing care.

behavioral_traits.emotional_resilience: Angela is calm under pressure, often handling stressful situations by taking time for self-care, like yoga or reading.

emotional_triggers.positive_triggers: Being acknowledged for her hard work makes Angela feel valued and empowered.
emotional_triggers.negative_triggers: Feeling unappreciated or dismissed makes her uncomfortable.

motivations.core_motivations: Personal growth and financial stability are key drivers for Angela.
motivations.emotional_motivations: Feeling appreciated at work and achieving personal goals gives her fulfillment.
motivations.extrinsic_motivations: Salary and recognition from her peers and supervisors are motivating factors.
motivations.intrinsic_motivations: Her passion for healthcare and curiosity about medical advancements drive her internally.

challenges.personal_challenges: Balancing her personal life with her demanding job schedule is a constant challenge.
challenges.professional_challenges: Keeping up with the latest medical procedures and technologies.
challenges.communication_challenges: Angela sometimes struggles with articulating her emotions effectively, especially in confrontational situations.

life_outside_work.social_circle: Angela maintains a tight-knit social group consisting mainly of family and close friends.

family_life.importance_of_family: Family is central to Angela's identity and a key motivator in her life.
family_life.family_role: She is a caregiver and supporter within her family.

life_outside_work.community_involvement: Angela volunteers at local health fairs and participates in community wellness events.

professional_goals.short_term_goals: Angela aims to earn a specialty certification to enhance her expertise in cardiac care.
professional_goals.long_term_goals: She aspires to become a nursing supervisor and advocate for patient care improvements.

frustrations_pain_points.personal_frustrations: Angela finds limited time for personal hobbies frustrating.
frustrations_pain_points.professional_frustrations: Administrative tasks and bureaucratic delays hinder her ability to spend more time with patients.
frustrations_pain_points.communication_frustrations: She feels frustrated when coworkers misunderstand her due to lack of clear communication.

daily_tasks.personal_routine: Angela starts her day with a morning run, followed by preparing her child for school and commuting to work.
daily_tasks.work_routine: Her workday includes patient rounds, updating medical records, and collaborating with doctors.

social_media_usage.purpose: Networking and staying updated with medical news

cognitive_biases.optimism_bias: Angela tends to overestimate the positive impact of her interventions on patient outcomes.
cognitive_biases.confirmation_bias: She often seeks information that confirms her patient care philosophy.
cognitive_biases.anchoring_bias: Her past successful experiences in patient care guide her current practices.
cognitive_biases.availability_bias: Recent successful patient recoveries often come to mind, influencing her treatment confidence.

response_to_interview_context.adaptability_during_interviews: Angela adjusts well to unexpected questions, taking time to think before responding thoughtfully.

customer_journey.awareness_stage: Angela becomes aware of new medical products through industry magazines and peer recommendations.
customer_journey.consideration_stage: She considers factors such as product reliability, reviews from colleagues, and cost-effectiveness.
customer_journey.decision_stage: Peer recommendations and product demonstrations influence her final decision.
customer_journey.post_purchase_behavior: After purchase, Angela often shares feedback with her network if she finds the product valuable.

transcript.text: Hello! Thank you for taking the time to speak with me today. I hope you're doing well. To start, can you tell me a bit about your role as a nurse and what your typical workday looks like?

Hi! Thanks for having me. As a nurse, my typical day revolves around patient care. I start with patient rounds, checking on their needs and how they're progressing. Updating medical records is a big part of the routine, and I spend time collaborating with the doctors on treatment plans. It's pretty busy, but seeing positive patient outcomes makes it all worth it.
Thank you for sharing that! It sounds like your days are quite busy and varied.  So, thinking about your busy daily routine, can you describe how it impacts your choice of footwear?

Oh, definitely! Comfort is key for me. Being on my feet for long hours means I need shoes that provide good support and cushioning. I usually go for something lightweight and breathable since I’m moving around a lot. Durable shoes also make a big difference because they need to handle a busy environment.
I see, comfort and durability seem to be very important. Can you share a bit more about some specific challenges you've faced with your current shoes during your shifts?

Yeah, sometimes the shoes don't hold up as well as I'd like with constant wear, leading to discomfort or sore feet by the end of the day. Also, if they aren't slip-resistant, it can be tricky navigating the hospital floors safely, especially when things get hectic. So, finding shoes that balance support, durability, and safety is definitely a challenge.

Thank you for that. It sounds like these issues can really impact your day. Have you ever experienced significant discomfort or pain due to your footwear at work? Could you elaborate on that experience?

Yeah, I have. There was a time when I hadn't replaced my shoes in a while, and they lost their cushioning. I ended up with really sore feet and even some back pain after long shifts. That taught me the importance of regularly checking and swapping out my shoes before they get too worn out. It's not something I want to repeat!
I understand, that sounds quite uncomfortable. Can you recall a specific moment or event that prompted you to consider changing your shoes? What led to that decision?

Sure, there was one really long shift where I was on my feet almost non-stop. By the end of it, my feet were aching, and it was hard to focus on anything else. It was frustrating because it affected my ability to provide the best care. After that day, I knew it was time to invest in a new pair of shoes that could better handle the demands of my job.
That makes a lot of sense. It must have been quite a realization. On a more positive note, what has been your most satisfying experience with a pair of shoes, and what made it stand out for you?

I remember finding a pair that had excellent arch support and cushioning, which made such a difference. It felt like walking on clouds, even on the longest days. The relief from discomfort let me focus more on my patients and less on my feet, which was a huge win. It definitely highlighted how crucial good footwear is in my line of work.
That sounds wonderful. It's great to hear how much of an impact the right shoes can have. Moving on a bit, what are the top three features you look for in a pair of work shoes?

The top three features I look for are comfort, durability, and slip-resistance. Comfort is a must for those long shifts, durability means they'll last through constant wear, and slip-resistance ensures safety when walking on hospital floors. These really make a difference for me on the job.
Those are certainly crucial features. Could you describe why comfort is more important to you compared to other factors like style or price when choosing shoes for work?

Comfort is crucial because when you're on your feet for hours at a time, any discomfort can quickly turn into pain and a major distraction. It impacts my ability to focus and care for patients effectively. While style and price do matter, they take a backseat to comfort because it's all about being able to do my job without unnecessary physical strain. Staying comfortable keeps me more efficient and focused.
I see, that makes a lot of sense. Could you then describe the level of support you need from a shoe for your daily activities at work?

I need a shoe with good arch support and cushioning. The arch support helps distribute my weight evenly and reduces strain on my feet. Cushioning is important for absorbing impact as I walk a lot during the day. These features help prevent foot fatigue and make it easier to get through those busy shifts comfortably.
Thank you for that detailed explanation. How do durability and longevity influence your decision when purchasing work shoes?

Durability is really important because my shoes need to withstand daily wear and tear. If a pair doesn't hold up, I end up spending more in the long run replacing them frequently. So, when choosing shoes, I look for something that's well-made and will last through constant use. It ensures I get good value for my investment, and I don't have to worry about them breaking down unexpectedly.
That makes sense; durability certainly seems essential for your work conditions. What role does slip resistance or grip play in your footwear choice for work?

Slip resistance is key, especially in a hospital setting where floors can be slick. Good grip reduces the risk of slipping and getting injured, which is vital for my safety and for those around me. It gives me confidence and peace of mind when moving quickly during a busy shift. So, I prioritize shoes with a reliable grip to ensure stability and safety at work.
It's clear how critical safety features are for your work environment. Transitioning to a different perspective, how do your shoes affect your confidence and mood during work?

When my shoes are comfortable and supportive, it boosts my confidence because I can focus on my patients and tasks without being distracted by foot pain. It puts me in a better mood knowing I'm prepared to handle whatever the day brings. On the flip side, wearing uncomfortable shoes can really dampen my mood, as it makes everything feel like more of a struggle. Comfortable footwear helps me start the day on a positive note.

It's interesting to hear how much of an impact footwear can have on your overall day. Can you describe any social influences that affect your shoe choices, such as opinions from colleagues or friends?

Definitely, colleagues and friends can have a big impact. We often share tips and recommendations, especially about brands or styles that have worked well. If a colleague mentions how a particular shoe really helped them during long shifts, I'm more likely to consider it. Hearing firsthand experiences from people in similar roles can be really reassuring and helpful in making decisions.
It's great to have that kind of support network. Switching gears a bit, how important is brand reputation to you when selecting shoes for work?

Brand reputation is somewhat important because it can indicate reliability and quality. If a brand is known for durable and comfortable shoes, I'm more likely to trust that they'll meet my needs. However, I still prioritize comfort and support features over brand alone. Reputation can guide my choices, but the actual performance and fit are what matter most to me in the end.
That makes sense—balancing reputation with actual functionality. How does the design or aesthetics of a shoe impact your decision, and in what way?

While design and aesthetics are less important than comfort and support, I'd still prefer something that looks professional and fits in with my work attire. A decent-looking shoe can complement my uniform and give a bit of a confidence boost. Ultimately, though, practicality comes first, so I won't choose a shoe solely based on style if it doesn't meet my comfort needs.
Understood, practicality is definitely key in your line of work. How do you feel when you wear shoes that meet all your expectations?

When I wear shoes that meet all my expectations, I feel prepared and confident. It's a relief to not have to worry about discomfort or slipping—it lets me concentrate fully on my duties. It really makes a positive difference in my overall day, keeping me more focused and positive.
It's great to hear how a good pair of shoes can positively impact your workday. Shifting focus slightly, how does your work environment influence your footwear needs?

The hospital environment definitely influences my footwear needs. It requires a lot of walking and standing, so I need shoes that provide excellent support and cushioning. The floors can get slick, especially in high-traffic areas, so slip-resistant soles are a must for safety. Plus, with the fast pace, shoes need to be durable enough to handle constant movement without wearing out quickly. All these factors shape what I look for in work shoes.
Thank you for that detailed insight. Are there specific seasons or conditions that change what you look for in a shoe?

Not too much, since I work indoors most of the time, but during colder months, I do look for shoes with a bit more warmth and maybe water-resistance for commuting. Otherwise, comfort, support, and slip-resistance remain my top priorities year-round because the hospital environment stays pretty consistent.
That makes sense, given the indoor setting of your work. How do budget or cost constraints affect your decision-making process for work shoes?

Budget certainly plays a role, but I see work shoes as an investment in my comfort and well-being. I try to find a balance between quality and cost, prioritizing features that are crucial for my long shifts. Sometimes spending a bit more on a reliable, durable pair ends up saving money in the long term since they'll last and provide the support I need.
That thoughtful approach makes a lot of sense. Can you walk me through your decision-making process when purchasing a new pair of work shoes?

Sure! First, I identify what features are crucial, like comfort, support, and slip-resistance. Then, I consider recommendations from colleagues and read reviews to narrow down options. I also keep my budget in mind to find a good balance between quality and cost. If possible, I try them on to see how they feel because fit is important. Once I've considered all these factors and found a pair that ticks all the boxes, I make the purchase.
It's clear you have a thoughtful and thorough process. How often do you perform an assessment of your current footwear, and what prompts this evaluation?

I usually assess my footwear every few months or if I start noticing discomfort or wear and tear. Any persistent aches or issues with support are clear signs that it's time for an evaluation. Keeping an eye on these things helps me stay proactive, so I can replace them before they impact my job performance or comfort too much.
Thank you for sharing that. Considering your experience, what specific pain points or frustrations drive you to seek new footwear options?

The main frustrations are persistent discomfort, lack of support, or feeling unsafe due to poor grip. If shoes start causing foot pain or backaches, it's a big motivator to look for new options. It's also frustrating when shoes wear out too quickly, especially if they don't provide the necessary support anymore. These issues prompt me to find a pair that better suits my needs.
That makes a lot of sense. Switching gears slightly, can you describe any recent experiences that made you consider changing your footwear?

Sure, there was this particular period when I had a series of long shifts back-to-back, and I noticed my shoes weren't providing the support they used to. My feet felt more fatigued than normal, which was a clear sign that it was time to look for a new pair. That's when I decided to seriously consider upgrading to something more supportive and comfortable for the demands of my job.
Thank you for sharing that recent experience. How do advancements in shoe technology or new product launches influence your purchasing decisions?

Advancements in shoe technology can be quite appealing, especially if they promise improved comfort or support. I often look into new product launches to see if they offer features that address my needs better, like enhanced cushioning or slip-resistance. If a new product has positive reviews from other healthcare professionals and fits within my budget, I might be inclined to give it a try. However, I do weigh these advancements against my essential criteria to ensure they truly provide the benefits I need.
That's insightful, balancing new technology with proven needs. What role do reviews or recommendations play in your decision to try new footwear?

Reviews and recommendations play a significant role for me. Hearing about firsthand experiences from others, especially fellow nurses, can be really reassuring. If a shoe comes highly recommended for comfort and durability, I'm more likely to consider it. Reviews can help highlight any potential issues or benefits I hadn't thought of, making them an important part of my decision-making process.
I can see how valuable those insights can be. Can you identify any emotional triggers that have led you to change your footwear in the past?

Definitely. A major emotional trigger is that feeling of frustration when I'm not at my best because of discomfort or pain from my shoes. It can be really disheartening when I can't focus on patient care because of my own physical discomfort. Also, feeling unsafe or unstable due to a lack of grip is another trigger. These situations push me to make a change because I value both my comfort and my ability to perform my job effectively.
Thank you for sharing those experiences. How do you perceive popular brands in the context of work footwear, and why?

Popular brands often come with a reputation for quality and reliability, which can be reassuring. If a brand is well-known for creating durable and comfortable work shoes, I'm more likely to consider it because it suggests they have a track record of meeting the needs of professionals like me. However, I still make sure to assess if their products truly fit my personal requirements rather than going solely by the brand name. Reputation helps, but actual comfort and performance are what ultimately drive my decision.
That balanced approach makes sense. Can you share your thoughts on how branding affects your trust in a shoe's performance?

Branding can definitely influence my trust in a shoe's performance, as established brands often back their products with a history of quality. If a brand has consistently delivered shoes that are comfortable and durable for work situations, I'm more inclined to trust their new products. However, I still rely on reviews and my own priorities to ensure that a specific shoe meets my needs because branding alone doesn't guarantee it will work for me. Trust is built over time through positive experiences with the brand's products.
I understand. Now, let's talk about aesthetics and current trends. How do these factors influence your decision when purchasing work shoes?

While aesthetics and trends aren't my top priority for work shoes, I do appreciate when a pair looks professional and well-suited to my work attire. If a shoe combines good looks with the comfort and support I need, it's definitely a plus. However, I won't compromise on key features like comfort and durability just to follow a trend. Functionality is essential, but it's nice when the shoes look good, too.
It's interesting how you balance functionality and style. Would you be willing to compromise on style for increased comfort and functionality? Why or why not?

Absolutely, I'd prioritize comfort and functionality over style for work shoes. My main focus is being able to perform my job effectively and comfortably. While style is nice to have, it doesn't outweigh the need for support and safety during long shifts. Being comfortable and supported helps me focus better on patient care, which is far more important to me than the shoe's appearance.
That certainly aligns with your priorities. How important is it for your work shoes to align with your personal fashion style?

It's not too important for my work shoes to align with my personal fashion style. While it's nice if they're somewhat in line with what I like, the main focus is on comfort and functionality for my job. Outside of work, I have more flexibility to express my style, but for work, practicality takes precedence over fashion. As long as the shoes are professional-looking and meet my work needs, that's what matters most.
I appreciate your perspective on that. Is there anything else you'd like to share about your experiences or preferences with work footwear?

I think we've covered most of it, but I'd add that finding the right work shoes really comes down to understanding your specific needs and priorities. Whether it's comfort, support, or safety features like slip-resistance, knowing what you value most is key. Trying out different options and listening to recommendations can really help in finding that perfect pair. Ultimately, a good pair of work shoes can make a huge difference in how you feel throughout the day.
Thank you for that additional insight. Do you have any suggestions for shoe companies to better meet the needs of nurses like yourself?

For shoe companies, focusing on enhancing support and cushioning would be great, along with ensuring durability for long-term use. Designing with input from healthcare professionals can help tailor features like slip-resistance and breathability. Offering a range of sizes and widths can accommodate diverse needs as well. Lastly, ensuring the shoes are easy to clean is a helpful bonus in a healthcare setting. These improvements would really make a difference for nurses.
Your suggestions are very insightful and practical. What would be the ultimate feature or innovation in footwear that would address all your needs?

The ultimate feature for me would be a shoe that combines exceptional comfort, with excellent arch support, cushioning, and breathability, along with top-notch slip-resistance and durability. An additional innovation might be shoes with customizable support options, like interchangeable insoles tailored to different foot needs. If they could also be lightweight and easy to clean, that would cover everything on my wish list for work footwear.
That sounds like an ideal combination of features. Can you summarize your ideal pair of work shoes in a few words?
Sure! I'd say my ideal work shoes are supportive, comfortable, durable, and safe.
Thank you so much for your detailed and thoughtful responses today. Is there anything else you'd like to share, or do you have any questions for me before we conclude?

You're welcome! I think we've covered everything. I don't have any questions, but I appreciate the conversation and the chance to share my thoughts. If there's anything else in the future, feel free to reach out. Thanks for having me!
